subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: international quikscript
msgSnippet: ... I should have said: to have to look up words in a pronunciation dictionary and then transpose the IPA transcription plus rhoticization into QS in order to
messageBody:
On 2008-11-04 Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
> To have to look up words in a
> pronunciation dictionary every so often is quite tedious.
>

I should have said: to have to look up words in
a pronunciation dictionary and then transpose
the IPA transcription plus rhoticization into
QS in order to know how to spell in QS is quite
tedious, when rather the learnt QS spelling itself
could serve as a guide for pronunciation, so
we would benefit from a dictionary/wordlist
spelled and sorted according to a standardized form
of QS designed so that one can deduce the pronunciation
of all major accents through simple pronunciation
rules like "In General American Ox is pronounced
the same as Ah". There would still be a residue
of words like "tomato" which could/should be spelled
differently by speakers of different accents and which
shold then be listed under all of these pronunciations
a dictionary, but it's hardly practical to list two
different spellings e.g. for all those words which
have Ox in RP but Ah in GA. Above all I don't think
non-native writers want to be told to spell as they
guess or imagine that a word should be pronounced in
the accent of English which they aim to speak. That
would be te reintroduce the some trouble we have with
TO by the back door.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
"C'est en vain que nos Josués littéraires crient
à la langue de s'arrêter; les langues ni le soleil
ne s'arrêtent plus. Le jour où elles se *fixent*,
c'est qu'elles meurent." (Victor Hugo)
